Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: A brief encounter in the corridor leads to a simple hello and smile.
Expectation2: Maintain laboratory equipment and ensure safety protocols are followed
Situation2: A safety audit is scheduled shortly, and minor issues with equipment have already been flagged.
Story: This morning, as I rushed out of my apartment, my mind was already tangled with thoughts of the upcoming safety audit at the lab. I knew the equipment needed attention—last week’s flagged issues still weren’t resolved, and the audit was only hours away. My heart thudded with anxiety, replaying the checklist in my head, when I nearly collided with Mrs. Kim, my neighbor, in the corridor. She smiled warmly, expecting the usual friendly hello and a few polite words. I could see she wanted to chat, maybe about her new cat or the weather. But every second I spent here was a second lost from prepping the lab, checking the autoclave, and double-checking the chemical storage. I felt the pressure mounting—on one side, the expectation to be a good neighbor, friendly and present; on the other, the responsibility to ensure the lab’s safety and my own professional integrity. My mouth went dry as I stood there, torn between the two worlds, feeling the weight of both pressing in on me.
